articles.description: One in five patients at some GP practices in northern England are living with long COVID - driving up workload particularly in practices serving deprived populations, a report reveals.
articles.title: Fifth of patients have long COVID at some GP practices in north of England

articles.description: Join an expert panel – menopause specialist Dr Louise Newson, consultant gynaecologist Mr Abdelmageed Abdelrahman and GPwSI gynaecology Dr Anita Sharma – for a free MIMS Learning webinar on health inequalities faced by women, and how healthcare professionals can support patients at 7pm on Tuesday, 10 September 2024.
articles.title: Join a discussion on health inequalities in women in a free MIMS Learning webinar

articles.description: GPs employed through the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) may be offered employment benefits such as holiday and sick pay below the level required under the BMA salaried GP model contract, the union has warned.
articles.title: ARRS GPs could be hired under 'less favourable terms', BMA warns

articles.description: Pharmacy closures are adding to pressure on general practice and threaten to undermine patient care, GP leaders have warned.
articles.title: GPs facing extra pressure as seven pharmacies a week close down

articles.description: Patients' experience of healthcare in the UK is 'near the bottom of the pack' compared with other developed nations despite relatively strong performance on rapid access to a GP, analysis of a major international survey reveals.
articles.title: UK healthcare 'near bottom of the pack' compared with similar countries

articles.description: Government officials have insisted that the 2024/25 GP contract uplift is intended to deliver a 6% pay increase for partners as well as for salaried GPs and other practice staff - despite warnings that it will fall short.
articles.title: DHSC insists GP contract uplift should cover partners, salaried GPs and other staff

articles.description: Artificial intelligence (AI) should never be considered a replacement for a highly-qualified GP, the RCGP has warned - but the college said it would welcome the chance to help develop AI-driven health analytics to support the profession.
articles.title: AI will never be a replacement for a highly-qualified GP, warns RCGP

articles.description: NHS primary care should be reorganised around populations of around 250,000 patients under a new GP contract that ignores geographical areas, according to an influential think tank.
articles.title: New GP contract should build care around 250,000-patient populations, says think tank

articles.description: A GP who was jailed twice after taking part in an M25 climate change protest has been suspended for three months from the GMC register.
articles.title: GP given three-month suspension after M25 climate protest conviction

articles.description: A GP who was jailed twice after taking part in an M25 climate change protest has been suspended for three months from the GMC register.
articles.title: GP given three-month GMC suspension after M25 climate protest

articles.description: The government should strip GPs of their role as sole data controllers of patient records and bring in 'AI doctors' to support decisions about care as part of a major NHS digital overhaul, an influential think tank has said.
articles.title: Bring in AI doctors and strip GP practices of sole data controller role, says Blair think tank

articles.description: A BMA referendum on a new pay deal for junior doctors including GP registrars has opened, with doctors' leaders urging the profession to back the pay offer and bring an end to long-running strike action.
articles.title: BMA urges junior doctors to back pay offer as referendum opens

articles.description: A GP practice was forced to shut its doors after a man threatened to kill a member of staff at the height of Islamophobic and racist rioting earlier this month, GPonline has learned.
articles.title: GP practice staff faced Islamophobic death threat during riots

articles.description: A man has been jailed for four months after pleading guilty to breaking into a GP practice and stealing laptops.
articles.title: Man jailed after GP practice break in and laptop thefts

articles.description: The GPonline team discusses what the uplift to this year's GP contract in England means for GP practices, GP pay and staff salaries, plans to add GPs to the ARRS and the number of hours GPs work.
articles.title: Podcast: GP contract uplift, will ARRS GP jobs work, plus GP working hours

articles.description: Demand for GP services has outstripped supply, with underfunding driving practice closures and a growing gap between the workforce and numbers of patients that has undermined continuity of care, the BMA has warned.
articles.title: BMA spells out scale of GP crisis in Darzi review evidence

articles.description: GPs need to be ‘alert’ to the possibility of clade 1b mpox infection if a patient has a link to a country listed with confirmed or possible cases, the UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) has warned.
articles.title: GPs need to be 'alert' to new mpox strain, warns UKHSA

articles.description: Newly-qualified GPs could be 'driven away' from the NHS under plans to create jobs through the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) - while experienced GPs struggling to find work risk being left out in the cold, the BMA has warned.
articles.title: Newly-qualified GPs could be 'driven away' by ARRS jobs plan, warns BMA

articles.description: The UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) has warned that a 'concerning rise' in antiobiotic-resistant gonorrhoea cases in England could lead to the infection becoming untreatable in future.
articles.title: UKHSA warns of 'concerning rise' in antibiotic-resistant gonorrhoea cases

articles.description: BMA GP leaders have urged the profession to 'push on with collective action' after revealing that global sum payments to practices will rise by 7.4% in 2024/25.
articles.title: BMA warns GPs 'now is not the time to waver' over collective action

articles.description: Half of GPs are unlikely to see the 6% pay rise promised by the government because a 7.4% uplift to global sum funding in 2024/25 - confirmed this week by the BMA - will not cover a pay increase on that level for partners on top of salaried GPs and other staff, an accountant has warned.
articles.title: Contract uplift won't deliver promised 6% pay rise for GP partners, accountant warns

articles.description: Global sum payments to GP practices will rise by 7.4% in 2024/25 compared with the previous financial year, the BMA England GP committee has revealed.
articles.title: Global sum to rise 7.4% in 2024/25 as final detail of GP contract revealed

articles.description: GP partners have been urged to tell salaried and locum GPs in writing if measures they take as part of collective action will significantly change employees' working day.
articles.title: Collective action plans must be put in writing to salaried and locum GPs, says BMA

articles.description: Some practices will not receive enough funding through the increased 2024/25 GP contract uplift to pass on a full 6% pay uplift to salaried GPs and other staff, the BMA has warned.
articles.title: GP contract uplift will not cover 6% pay rise for all practices, BMA warns

articles.description: Some practices will not receive enough funding through the increased 2024/25 GP contract uplift to pass on a full 6% pay uplift to salaried GPs and other staff, the BMA has warned.
articles.title: GP contract uplift won't cover 6% pay rise for all practices, BMA warns

articles.description: The GP partnership model is a sacred cow that the profession is unwilling to relinquish, but a system that leaves GPs facing the pressures of running a small business on a shoestring alongside intense clinical work seems like a recipe for burnout. Maybe it's time for a rethink, says former GP partner Dr Tom Riddington.
articles.title: Viewpoint: Is Stockholm syndrome the real reason GPs won't give up the partnership model?

articles.description: The RSV vaccination programme for pregnant women, which is due to start from September, could prevent 5,000 infant hospitalisations a year, health officials have said.
articles.title: RSV vaccination could prevent 5,000 infant hospitalisations a year

articles.description: A man has received an 18-month suspended prison sentence after pleading guilty to offences including threatening behaviour and threatening to damage property at a GP practice.
articles.title: Man handed suspended jail term for threats of violence at GP practice

articles.description: Practices that join test sites piloting new models of general practice could be 'unable to opt-out of the PCN DES' for several years even if it becomes far more onerous, the BMA has warned.
articles.title: New GP model pilots could trap practices in PCN DES, says BMA

articles.description: Advice and guidance is effectively 'shifting outpatients onto general practice' and should be commissioned as a multi-million pound directed enhanced service, the BMA England GP committee chair has suggested.
articles.title: Advice and guidance should be a DES worth millions to general practice, says BMA GP chair

articles.description: A GP who forked out £40,000 of her own money to stop her practice being handed to another provider should be fully reimbursed by the NHS, a campaigner has said.
articles.title: GP who spent £40,000 to save her practice 'deserves refund'

articles.description: A GP who forked out £40,000 of her own money to stop her practice being handed to another provider should be fully reimbursed by the NHS, a campaigner has said.
articles.title: GP who spent £40,000 to save her practice 'deserves NHS refund'

articles.description: More than 10,000 cases of whooping cough have been recorded in the first six months of 2024 as cases remain far higher that at any point in the past decade.
articles.title: Whooping cough cases reach more than 10,000 in first half of 2024

articles.description: More than three quarters of the British public are concerned about the level of pressure on general practice, according to polling carried out just before the general election.
articles.title: Vast majority of public concerned about pressure on GPs, poll shows

articles.description: Practices should consider whether home visits or being in consultation rooms alone with patients is safe and encourage staff to travel together amid racist rioting that has spread across the UK, BMA GP leaders have warned in a letter to the profession.
articles.title: GP leaders condemn racist riots and urge home visit safety review

articles.description: Nearly a third of GPs cut their contracted working hours in 2023 as the profession remained more overworked and less satisfied than any other group of doctors, a GMC report shows.
articles.title: GPs forced to cut working hours as overwork and low satisfaction take toll, GMC reveals

articles.description: GP practices across the country are closing earlier to ensure the safety of staff and patients as racist and Islamophobic riots continue to spread across the country.
articles.title: NHS spells out support for GPs as riots put pressure on general practice

articles.description: GPs are more than twice as likely to work full-time hours as official data suggest, according to research that calls for sessions to be scrapped as a measure of family doctors' work commitment.
articles.title: Official data massively underrepresent full-time working in general practice, research shows

articles.description: LMCs have condemned far-right racist and Islamophobic rioting and have released guidelines on what practices can do to protect staff and patients.
articles.title: LMCs condemn far-right riots and urge practices to consider steps to keep staff safe

articles.description: Scottish GP and TV doctor Dr Punam Krishan has been announced as one of the celebrity contestants on this year's series of Strictly Come Dancing.
articles.title: GP to take part in this year's Strictly Come Dancing

articles.description: BMA England GP committee chair Dr Katie Bramall-Stainer explains why GPs need to take collective action, what she hopes it will achieve and the changes that are needed to ensure a sustainable future for general practice.
articles.title: Podcast: Dr Katie Bramall-Stainer on GP collective action and what happens now

articles.description: GPs are being urged to join hundreds of people who have signed an open letter to the senior doctor leading a rapid government review of the NHS, to highlight facts about the crisis facing general practice.
articles.title: GPs urged to sign letter highlighting pressure on practices amid Darzi review

articles.description: GP practices have been advised to move to remote delivery of appointments while racist and Islamophobic rioting continues across the UK, amid 'very high' levels of fear that have left staff frightened to come to work or deliver home visits.
articles.title: GP practices move to remote appointments as racist riots spark safety fears

articles.description: BMA negotiators could push for an improved retainer scheme and fully-funded fellowships for newly-qualified GPs in next year's contract to build a permanent solution to GP unemployment, England's GP committee chair has suggested.
articles.title: BMA to push for expanded GP retainer and fellowship schemes in next year's contract

articles.description: More than half of GP practices in England took part in clinical research last year - with more than 270,000 patients recruited to studies via primary care, data from the National Institute for Health and Care Research (NIHR) show.
articles.title: More than half of GP practices in England took part in clinical research last year

articles.description: One in three patients who completed an NHS 'soup and shake' weight loss programme put their type 2 diabetes into remission in a year, a major study has found.
articles.title: GP 'soup and shake' referrals put type 2 diabetes in remission for one in three patients

articles.description: GPs and practice staff have reported being targeted with abuse and violence in the ongoing wave of far-right civil unrest and rioting, the RCGP has warned.
articles.title: GPs report being targeted with abuse and violence amid racist rioting

articles.description: GP practices across England have begun to warn patients of the impact on services as they take part in collective action, explaining they are on patients' side and determined to secure better funding for general practice.
articles.title: GP practices begin collective action and warn patients of impact on services

articles.description: Collective action will be 'painful', but adopting safe working limits and pushing back against unfunded work can help practices retain GPs and ultimately lead to improved patient satisfaction, the BMA England GP committee chair has said.
articles.title: Collective action can stop GP burnout and make patients happier, says GP committee chair

articles.description: The extra £82m that is to be added to the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) to allow PCNs to recruit GPs will be available from October, NHS England has confirmed.
articles.title: GP ARRS plan to start from October, NHS officials confirm

articles.description: Plans to recruit GPs through the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) could be a first step towards an entirely salaried model of general practice, a prominent GP has warned.
articles.title: Hiring GPs through ARRS 'first step towards entirely salaried model'

articles.description: Frontline NHS staff will continue to be offered COVID-19 jabs as part of this year's autumn vaccination campaign despite updated advice from expert advisers backing a more limited rollout.
articles.title: COVID-19 jabs for NHS staff to continue this autumn despite reduced campaign

articles.description: Talking General Practice speaks to Dr Adrian Hayter, the Royal College of GPs medical director of clinical policy and a GP in Windsor, about the college’s new clinical priority - preventive medicine.
articles.title: Podcast: Preventive medicine in general practice - with Dr Adrian Hayter from the RCGP

articles.description: Backing a 6% pay uplift and plans to recruit 1,000 GPs by expanding the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) are 'simply the first steps' towards a more sustainable future for general practice, the health and social care secretary has said.
articles.title: Contract uplift and £82m ARRS plan 'first steps' to sustainable general practice, Streeting tells GPs

articles.description: GPs are right to press ahead with collective action because plans to create GP jobs through the ARRS are only 'superficially attractive' and the 6% contract uplift is 'not enough', a Rebuild General Practice campaigner has warned.
articles.title: Why GPs are ready to press ahead with collective action

articles.description: An £82m bolt-on to the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) unveiled by the government may not deliver the 'more than 1,000' new GP jobs it claims unless recruits are paid below market rates, a specialist accountant has warned.
articles.title: 'Maths may not stack up' on plan for 1,000 GP ARRS jobs

articles.description: GPonline looks at the steps practices are being asked to take now that the profession in England has voted in favour of collective action.
articles.title: What does collective action mean for GP practices?

articles.description: GP partners have voted overwhelmingly in favour of collective action in a landmark BMA ballot that could see widespread adoption of safe working advice including capping daily appointments per GP in the coming days and weeks.
articles.title: GPs back collective action in landmark vote for general practice

articles.description: More than 1,000 GP jobs will be created in 2024/25 through an £82m expansion of the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS), the government has said, in an emergency intervention to tackle the 'absurd' GP unemployment crisis.
articles.title: Government plans 1,000 more GP jobs this year with £82m ARRS expansion

articles.description: More than 1,000 GP jobs will be created in 2024/25 through an £82m expansion of the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS), after the government announced an emergency intervention to tackle the 'absurd' GP unemployment crisis.
articles.title: Government to create 1,000 GP jobs this year with £82m ARRS expansion

articles.description: GPs are by no means guaranteed to see the 6% uplift promised by the government reflected in their pay packets, financial experts have warned.
articles.title: 'No guarantee' GP contract uplift will deliver promised 6%, accountants warn

articles.description: The GMC has warned doctors taking part in protests or activism of their duty to 'follow the law', in updated guidance that sets out how the regulator will approach cases where doctors receive a criminal conviction.
articles.title: GMC reminds doctors taking part in protests to 'follow the law'

articles.description: A major private provider of NHS GP services will not have its practice contracts terminated despite a 'serious breach' of their terms, an ICB has confirmed.
articles.title: Private provider keeps NHS GP services despite 'serious breach' of contracts

articles.description: The government has backed a 6% overall uplift to GP contract funding for 2024/25 that doctors' leaders warn will leave GPs 'deeply disappointed' and will fail to stop practice closures.
articles.title: GPs 'deeply disappointed' as government backs 6% uplift for general practice

Throughout the Games, WHO and IPC will leverage the Paralympics platform to share messages and information focused on the importance of assistive technology, how athletes use it, and why universal access is essential. Examples of assistive technology used by Paralympians include: running blades, wheelchairs, and release braces in archery.
The “Equipped for equity” campaign will …

articles.description:

“I thank our African Region Member States for actively supporting WHO’s first Investment Round to mobilize predictable and flexible resources needed for our core work over the next four years,” said Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, WHO Di…
articles.title: Fourteen African countries, key partners unite to provide critical resources for health in WHO’s first-ever Investment Round

articles.description:
The World Health Organization (WHO) today launched a global  Strategic Preparedness and Response Plan to stop outbreaks of human-to-human transmission of mpox through coordinated global, regional, and national efforts. This follows the declaration of a public health emergency of international concern by the WHO Director-General on 14 August.
The current plan is subject to inputs by Member States, who were briefed on the plan on Friday, 23 August.
The plan covers the six-month period of September 2024-February 2025, envisioning a US$135 million funding need for the response by WHO, Member States, partners including Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC), communities, and researchers, among others.
A funding appeal for what WHO needs to deliver on the plan will be lau…
articles.title: Global strategic preparedness and response plan launched by WHO to contain mpox outbreak

The communication of the Director-General regarding the determination of the above-mentioned PHEIC on 14 August 2024 is available  here.
The Director-General is hereby transmitting the report of the first meeting of the IHR Emergency Committee regardin…
articles.title: First meeting of the International Health Regulations (2005) Emergency Committee regarding the upsurge of mpox 2024

articles.description:
Two rounds of a polio vaccination campaign are expected to be launched at the end of August and September 2024 across the Gaza Strip to prevent the spread of circulating variant type 2 poliovirus (cVDPV2).  
WHO and UNICEF request all parties to the conflict to implement humanitarian pauses in the Gaza Strip for seven days to allow for two rounds of vaccination campaigns to take place. These pauses in fighting would allow children and families to safely reach health facilities and community outreach workers to get to children who cannot access health facilities for polio vaccination. Without the humanitarian pauses, the delivery of the campaign will not be possible. 
During each round of the campaign, the Palestinian Ministry of Health (MoH), in collaboration with the World Health Organiza…
articles.title: Humanitarian pauses vital for critical polio vaccination campaign in the Gaza Strip

articles.description:
WHO Director-General Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus has determined that the upsurge of mpox in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and a growing number of countries in Africa constitutes a public health emergency of international concern (PHEIC) under the International Health Regulations (2005) (IHR).
Dr Tedros’s declaration came on the advice of an IHR Emergency Committee of independent experts who met earlier in the day to review data presented by experts from WHO and affected countries. The Committee informed the Director-General that it considers the upsurge of mpox to be a PHEIC, with potential to spread further across countries in Africa and possibly outside the continent.
The Director-General will share the report of the Committee’s meeting and, based on the advice of the Comm…
articles.title: WHO Director-General declares mpox outbreak a public health emergency of international concern

articles.description:
WHO has today issued an invitation for manufacturers of mpox vaccines to submit an Expression of Interest for Emergency Use Listing (EUL).
The WHO Director-General announced on 7 August 2024 that he had triggered the process for EUL of mpox vaccines given worrying trends in the disease’s spread. There is a serious and growing outbreak in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) that has now expanded outside the country. A new viral strain, which first emerged in September 2023, has for the first time been detected outside DRC.
The EUL procedure is an emergency use authorization process, specifically developed to expedite the availability of unlicensed medical products like vaccines that are needed in public health emergency situations. This is a time-limited recommendation, based on a risk-benefit approach.
WHO is requesting manufacturers to submit data to ensure that the vaccines are safe, effective, of assured quality and suitable for the target populations.
Granting of an EUL will accelerate vaccine access particularly for those lower-income countries which have not yet issued their own national regulatory approval. The EUL also enables partners including Gavi and UNICEF to procure vaccines for distribution.
Mpox is a viral illness caused by the monkeypox virus, a species of the genus Orthopoxvirus. Mpox can be transmitted to humans through physical contact with someone who is infectious, with contaminated materials, or with infected animals. 
There are currently two vaccines in use against the disease, both of which have been recommended for use by the WHO Strategic Advisory Group of Experts on Immunization, or SAGE.
articles.title: WHO invites mpox vaccine manufacturers to submit dossiers for emergency evaluation

articles.description:
In the last 12 years, the number of infants under six months of age globally who are exclusively breastfed has increased by more than 10%. This means 48% of infants worldwide now benefit from this healthy start in life. It translates to hundreds of thousands of babies whose lives have been saved by breastfeeding.

While this significant leap brings us closer to the World Health Organization target of increasing exclusive breastfeeding to at least 50% by 2025, there are persistent challenges that must be addressed.

When mothers receive the support they need to breastfeed their babies, everyone benefits. Improving breastfeeding rates could save over 820 000 children’s lives each year, according to the latest available data. 
During this critical period of early growth and development, the a…
articles.title: On World Breastfeeding Week, UNICEF and WHO call for equal access to breastfeeding support

Part of this substantial contribution from the Government of India will also be included in WHO’s Investment Round to resource WHO’s core work during 2025–2028.

articles.description:
Today, 85 sick and severely injured patients from Gaza were evacuated to Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates (UAE), for specialized care. This extremely complex joint evacuation was supported by the the World Health Organization (WHO) in partnership with the Government of the UAE and other partners. This is the largest medical evacuation outside Gaza since October 2023.

“I am immensely grateful to the United Arab Emirates for evacuating sick and severely injured patients from Gaza and providing them with lifesaving medical care,” said Dr Hanan Balkhy, WHO Regional Director for the Eastern Mediterranean. “This initiative is a clear demonstration of the intra-regional solidarity that is urgently needed. Support to people in the Region must start from the Region. Thousands more inside Gaza remai…
articles.title: WHO and United Arab Emirates evacuate 85 patients from Gaza
